skill.name: Frontend Components
skill.description: Build reusable, composable UI components with single responsibilities, clear prop interfaces, proper state management, and minimal coupling. Use this skill when creating or editing React components (.tsx, .jsx files), when designing component APIs with props, when implementing component composition patterns, when managing local component state, when building shadcn/ui components, when creating shared UI components in resources/js/Components/, when implementing component documentation, or when refactoring large components into smaller, focused pieces.

security_audit.summary: This is a prompt engineering skill containing only documentation and guidelines. No executable code, no network calls, no filesystem access beyond reading itself. Pure informational skill with no security concerns.

content.value_statement: Creating reusable React components that follow best practices can be challenging without clear guidance. This skill provides structured patterns for component composition, state management, and prop design to help developers build maintainable UI libraries.
actual_capabilities: Create React components in .tsx and .jsx files
Design component prop interfaces and TypeScript types
Manage component state with useState and useReducer
Refactor monolithic components into smaller focused pieces
limitations: Does not execute code or run tests
Does not generate full application code independently
Provides guidance only, requires developer implementation
Focused on React, may not apply to other frameworks

prompt_templates.title: Create Button Component
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating a new button with variants
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Button component with primary, secondary, and danger variants. Include loading state and disabled prop.

prompt_templates.title: Design Card API
prompt_templates.prompt: Design the TypeScript interface for a Card component with optional header, footer, and hover effects.

prompt_templates.title: Extract Subcomponents
prompt_templates.prompt: Refactor this UserProfile component by extracting the header, avatar, and stats sections into separate components.

prompt_templates.title: Implement Form Composition
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Form component using composition with FormField, FormLabel, FormError, and FormSubmit subcomponents.

output_examples.input: Create a Modal component with proper state management and accessibility
output: - Use useState for open/close state with isOpen prop for controlled usage
- Add useEffect for escape key listener and focus trap
- Include onClose callback prop for external state updates
- Add portal rendering for proper z-index handling

best_practices: Keep components small with single responsibility - one component should do one thing well
Use TypeScript interfaces for props to create clear, documented component APIs
Prefer composition over inheritance when combining components and behaviors
anti_patterns: Avoid large monolithic components with multiple unrelated responsibilities
Do not expose internal component state unless necessary (prop drilling anti-pattern)
Avoid tight coupling between unrelated components through shared state

faq.question: What frameworks does this skill support?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on React with TypeScript. Patterns may apply to other component-based frameworks with adaptation.

faq.question: What is the maximum component complexity supported?
faq.answer: The skill handles components from simple buttons to complex compound components with multiple subcomponents.

faq.question: How does this integrate with shadcn/ui?
faq.answer: The skill provides guidance on customizing and combining shadcn/ui components for specific use cases.

faq.question: Is data stored or shared when using this skill?
faq.answer: No data is stored or shared. This is a prompt guidance skill with no persistent state or external calls.

faq.question: What if components do not follow patterns correctly?
faq.answer: The skill provides guidelines that developers implement manually. Code review and testing verify correct application.

faq.question: How does this compare to other component libraries?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on architecture patterns rather than pre-built components. It complements any UI library.
